definition[0]: used in writing after a list to show that there are many other similar things or people that you could have added
example[0]: a shop which sells cards, calendars, wrapping paper etc
example[1]: The letter says pay at once, they’ve reminded us before etc. etc.
explanation[0]: When writing essays, articles, or business letters, people usually avoid using etc. or etcetera, and write the sentence another way using such as:
definition[1]: used when you want to say that there are many other examples of things of the same kind. The full form is et cetera, but this is rarely used. Don’t use etc. in essays or formal writing
example[2]: They asked me about my past experience, qualifications etc.
example[3]: Precise details of times, dates etc. should be recorded.
definition[2]: used before one or more nouns to say that there are many other examples of the same kind. It is better to use such as rather than etc. in essays and formal writing
example[4]: It is best to avoid drinks such as tea, coffee or alcohol.
example[5]: a distressing event such as the break-up of a marriage
definition[3]: used after examples of something when saying that there are many more you could have mentioned
example[6]: Our daily activities include tennis, swimming, darts, snooker to name but a few.
definition[4]: used in spoken English when you want to say that there are other examples of things of the same kind. Don’t use and so on in essays or formal writing – it sounds too vague
example[7]: You can do things to look after yourself in the way of diet, exercise, not smoking and so on.
definition[5]: and many other people or things
example[8]: The book includes poems by Christina Rossetti, William Blake and many others.
example[9]: The college offers courses in maths, physics, computer science and many others.
definition[6]: et cetera; used after a list to show that there are other similar things or people that could have been added
example[10]: Loans have been taken out to cover the cost of repairs, new equipment etc.
